Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2013 10:35AM - edited Jul 2, 2013 10:36AM by brandall I know in my case that they did radiation locally to my chest wall in hopes for a "cure".  There is some evidence out there that treating people who have very few mets aggressively from the very begininng have had benefits.  Because I only had one lesion in my liver that was taken care of by chemo, they decided to do the chest wall rads (which they would give someone with a lesser stage) in hopes that treating aggressively might put me in that 1-2% of people who are cured of stage IV breast cancer.  I think a lot of factors swayed the tumor board into making that decision.  One, I was 36 (now 37), two, I already had the mastectomy before finding out stage IV status, three, I only had one liver lesion, and four, that lesion disappeared with chemo.  Will it work?  Who knows, but I do appreciate their optimism ;) It's my understanding that you meet some of that same criteria...so maybe that is why? Also, I think they can only radiate areas once, so if you have no evidence of disease in those areas currently, they might wish to keep radiation in their "back pocket" in case the mets do return to those areas. And...the biggest risk of reoccurance, for the same cancer and a new occurrance are in the same area of your original tumor (which now would be along the mastectomy scar).  That is why they do the boost to the mastectomy scar, to try and kill any of the small cells of cancer that might be hanging out there. I'm certainly no expert on this subject, so I might be wrong on some of the points above - it's just my experience :) P.S. are you getting rads in Denver?

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 01:55PM brandall wrote: I had a total hysterectomy last March.  I was originally just going to have the Oopherectomy, but since I was going on Tamoxifen (which has a slight risk of uterine cancer) we figured just take it all since they were already going to be in there.  It was a surprisingly easy surgery.  I had mine out because I wanted to have all of the post-menopausal AI's opened up to me in case of progression.  I recently had a progression to a lymph node in my upper abdomen and I was able to go on Femara (a post-menopausal drug) right away.   Your ovaries are not the only estrogen producers in your body.  Your adrenal glands produce estrogen and so does fat and muscle.  Good luck!  It sounds like a lot is being thrown at you at once, I know how overwhelming everything can be.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 11:11AM brandall wrote: I had mine out as a stage IV patient.  I had a total love/hate relationship with that thing.  I loved that it was easy to access, but I could feel it every time I moved my neck and that weird feeling made me want to vomit.  My oncologist had no problems with me removing it.  The surgeon who removed it was an ass and kept trying to talk me out of it.  He actually said, "It is stupid to get rid of this if you are just going to need it again in 6 months."  Jerk.  Obviously, I was hoping for more than 6 months without needing it!  I had it out 17 months ago and have no regrets.  I have had progression since then, but so far I've just switched to different AI's.   If you don't like it, I say get it out :)

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 11:33AM brandall wrote: I just don't like when people say, "You are such an inspiration".  I understand that they mean well, and I would never say anything to them about it, but I'm not an inspiration.  I'm just working on getting up every morning and living.  I haven't started an organization, made the world better on a grand scale, sacrificed for the greater good, cured cancer, etc...nothing inspirational ;)  I just feel very fraudulant when they say that. This was my first October having had cancer and it was AWFUL.  EVERY commercial was about early prevention and if you find cancer early it's largely curable.  BLAH!  Well, what about people like me, where is MY early prevention?  I had a breast exam in January which was unremarkable.  I wasn't "old" enough to get a mammogram according to my insurance, and I found a lump in May that by the time I had scans was stage IV at age 36.  So that early prevention crap pissed me off.  I am NOT looking forward to next October!  Plus every one started sending me "pink" stuff.  Really nice of them, but really just not my cup of tea :(  I now have drawers full of pink gear that I don't really know what to do with.  I look terrible in pink ;)

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 12:53AM brandall wrote: I'm 36 years old and was diagnosed pretty much from the get go with stage IV this past July.  My husband and I will be married for 10 years this coming November and the IL's just gave me a trip to Hawaii for our anniversary for my birthday (on the 17th of this month), woohoo!  I love to travel!  I have two amazing children, a daughter who is 6 (2006) and a son who is 3 (2009).  I pray every day that I will get to see them grow up and help them navigate the teenage years.  Mostly I hope that I don't go so soon that my son won't remember me :( I had one small liver met that started out at 1.3cm.  There were also 2 smaller spots seen on my liver that they assumed were mets.  All of the tumors were too small to biopsy and were in the middle of my liver.  Everyone is assuming that they are mets based on how they behaved on an MRI with Eovist and the fact that they responded to chemo and my once slightly elevated tumor markers have gone now.  The good news is that my latest PET scan in December 2012 showed no active cancer and that my liver lesion is now "resolved"  Yay!  Oddly enough there was a suspicious spot on my spleen that showed up on an MRI in November.  All of the oncologists felt that it was highly unlikely that breast cancer would travel to the spleen and it didn't light up on the PET scan, so who the heck knows what that is/was? Right now I'm feeling pretty great!  I'm trying to lose the 30lbs I put on with chemo :(  And my hair has started growing back.  It's just barely there right now, but my whole head is covered with a fuzzy layer of hair :)

Posts.Content: brandall wrote: This topic has caused me much stress!  I asked my first Onc if there were any foods I should stay away from.  He said to try and limit sugar and pretty much just get my sugars from fruit.  I then read Kris Carr's, "Crazy, Sexy, Cancer" books and freaked myself out.  She basically recommends a vegan diet.  I then asked my new Onc, the same question and he said that he hadn't heard any convincing arguments on restricting things except to eat a low-fat diet.  Next, I went to an oncology nutritionist.  She said that dairy was fine, but to make sure it was organic and drink/eat it sparingly. For every red meat meal I eat that I should eat 4 non-red meat meals.  As far as sugar goes that it is okay in small doses but to definitely try and limit it. I have to confess that going to a total vegan diet would be very hard for me.  Mostly due to the limited dairy thing.  I think I could give up red meat.  Limiting sugar would be tough, but do-able. I do feel that this is probably the only area of things that I can control.  However, all of the articles you read seem to contradict each other, it's terribly stressful to know exactly what is and is not a problem.  I also struggle with the idea of limiting my diet so much that life is not enjoyable.  Then again, I don't want to be on my death bed thinking, "I could have done more!". So what, if anything do you guys do? Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 09:08AM brandall wrote: Oh Kay, I know how stressful this must be!  Definitely don't jump to conclusions just yet!  Did they ultrasound your other organs, or just your liver?  The reason I ask is that I've had several instances of abdominal pain before cancer that turned out to be other things.  In fact, my liver mets never hurt or bothered me in any way.  A week after I had my last baby, I went to the ER with severe right sided pain, it was so bad that I started thinking I was having a heart attack.  When I got to the ER, they thought maybe it was a pulmonary embolism.  When that was ruled out with a CT, the ER doc told me I was having a panic attack and to go home.  Well after 3 more attacks in 3 days, I went to see my PCP who told me it was GERD, but humored me and ordered an ultrasound on my gallbladder anyway and it was full of stones.  Those stones did not show up on the CT, they had to find them with ultrasound.  Also, I have had several kidney stones which also cause extreme abdominal pain.  The liver is also often filled with benign hemangiomas and cysts, so don't panic yet!  I'll be thinking positive thoughts for your scan on Wednesday!  Let me know if you need to get together between now and then so I can talk you down off the ledge in person! Hugs to you!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2015 03:52PM brandall wrote: I'm the one who posted this originally. I posted this in May of 2013 freaked out because while still in the normal range, my tumor markers were rising. I can tell you that I did NOT have progression until February of 2014. So I think the answer is YES, you can have rising tumor markers still in the normal range and be fine. As I recall, my tumor markers did go down again a little bit and fluctuated quite a bit in the normal range. My tumor markers are very reliable. When they started creeping above the normal range I had progression visible on scans very shortly afterwards. Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2014 04:49AM brandall wrote: I identify a lot with your blog post and I am really pleased that a lot of what Dr. Valero said was the same thing that my Oncologist here recommended.  I have a similar story.  I was NED after chemo (and hoping I was in the small percent that would be "cured") and I had a small spot of cancer crop up in a lymph node in my upper abdomen this past February (a little over a year out from chemo).  It was a blow and I really had to readjust my thinking.  It was recommended to me by two oncologists (one being an expert on bc in women under age 45) that I should go right to a clinical trial.  I have been on the Paloma-3 trial, which is Faslodex plus a 2/3 chance of getting Palbociclib (CDK inhibitor) vs. Placebo.  I went on that trial in June and at the end of July my scans showed tumor shrinkage. I VERY strongly feel that there will not be a cure for a breast cancer.  I really think that it is going to become a chronic condition that will have to be constantly medicated.  We may have to constantly change medication, but there are going to be more and more inhibitors out there to choose from.  I am just hoping for time out of each medication for science to keep creating new drugs.  The expert I referenced above explained that the current approach to breast cancer in the lab (I go to a research hospital) is that estrogen positive breast cancer is like a bowl of alphabet soup.  We currently have shut down the ER (estrogen - with ooph and drugs) food source and unfortunately cancer is smart.  So the cancer says, "Well there is hardly any ER to eat, so let's start trying to eat CDK or P13".  We have to then shut down those pathways and try to get the cancer to seek out ER again, since there is so little there to begin with.  They eventually hope to find out how to shut down all of the "letters" in the alphabet soup and keep in in the bowl so to speak.  Thinking about it that way really helped me. So I guess to answer your question, I believe the answer to cancer is going to be more in the "continuously treating throughout my life" approach and I'm okay with that.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2013 05:35PM brandall wrote: When I went to get my port out in January, the surgeon gave me a hard time.  I loved the port for chemo, but never really liked the feeling in my neck and just wanted it out to feel "normal" for awhile.  He kept pushing for me to keep it in and I said, "I would really prefer to have it out right now", then he said, "well, it will be a total waste for us to take it out if you just plan on using it again in 6 months...do you think you'll need it in 6 months, you probably will right?"  Thanks ASS.  Actually, I'm hoping never to need it again, but I'm sure hoping I'll get more than 6 months without it - since that will mean that my tumors grow back and hormonals will have failed me.  Just no bedside manner. I also had a nurse go to take my blood pressure on my left side.  I told her that I can't have my pressure taken on that side.  She asked why and I told her that I had had a axillary node dissection.  She then said, "Wow, you know more than me" and she was completely serious... And the best (worst!) one was my oncologist's care coordinator.  I had a PET scan and a small spot lit up in my liver.  They were hoping it was a hemangioma and sent me to have an MRI to see if it was cancer.  The first MRI was inconclusive, so they did another MRI with Eovist.  The coordinator called me with the results and said, "Well, the radiologist feels it's cancer.  Dr. XXX wanted me to specifically tell you that he has a patient with a small liver spot like yours, who is 5 years out now with NED (I'm feeling encouraged by this news!) then she goes on to say, "Of course, on the flip side you could die in 6 months"  WTH!  Why add the "flip side" comment in there?  Do you think that I'm an idiot?  The MINUTE I heard the words, "you have cancer" I started thinking about the darn flip side.  Thanks lady.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2014 11:19PM brandall wrote: This trial was one of the options I was looking at when I chose the trial I am currently on (palbociclib w/ faslodex).  In the end I chose the Palbociclib trial because I had a 66% chance of getting the trial drug vs placebo and with the Belle 3 trial there was only a 50% chance.  That is literally the only thing that swayed me in one direction vs. the other.  I asked 2 different oncologists (at different facilities) which trial they thought was better and both of them felt they were both really promising drugs.  They couldn't really say one was better than the other and both suggested to go for the palbociclib trial solely on the premise that I had a better shot at actually getting the trial drug.  One of the side effects they have found with Belle 3 is some depression, so if you are naturally prone to that, you might want to take that under consideration.  They will have you fill out a lot of paperwork each time, trying to screen for that.  I remember that from my sit down with the trial coordinator.   If you decide to go on it, I would love to hear how you are doing!  Good luck with your decision!

Posts.Content: brandall wrote: A bit of background - when they did my first PET scan (last summer) 4 weeks after my mastectomy, a spot in my liver lit up.  It was tiny and the oncologist thought it might be a hemangioma.  It was too small to biopsy.  I had an MRI done and the results were inconclusive.  I had another MRI done with Eovist contrast and the radiologist felt it was "Likely" cancer.  Chemo completely took care of the spot, which gave them further evidence that it was probably cancer.  I've been NED since last December.  Last month I had tumor markers drawn and while they were still way within normal range at 19, for the first time, they had rose instead of went down.  They were only up 5 points...but still. I had a PET on Monday and called for the results today.  There was a small amount of metabolic activity in the right hepatic lobe.  It was only slightly greater than the background liver and this type of activity can be seen in a normal liver, but given my history it is concerning for the beginning of a new metastisis and should be the focus of my next PET. I'm scared :(  I'm tired of the "is it or isnt it" roller coaster.  I'm just tired :(  I have a regularly scheduled appointment with my oncologist on Monday, so I guess I'll know more then.  He'll let me see the scan too, which is always nice.  Plus I will get to pore over the written report vs. just getting it verbally from the nurse.  To be honest, once it sounded like there might be something bad on the scan the ringing in my ears was so loud it was hard to focus on what she might be saying. The SUV to that area was 2.1.  Does anyone know if that is good, bad, terrible?  I'm having my tumor markers drawn again tomorrow, so I guess we get see if they are still rising. Ugh. Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2014 12:33AM brandall wrote: Wrenn, I guess I see things a little bit differently in terms of educating people.  I do try to educate my friends.  I find they are woefully unaware of what stage IV breast cancer really means.  I get the following comments ALL.THE.TIME. - When are you going to be done with treatment?  Never, hoping this treatment will stick around for a few years before I have to move to the next one - This drug could cure you right?  No, there is no cure for breast cancer.  I'm hoping this treatment will work for many years though! - Your scans show no cancer, yay you beat it!  No, it is still there, just so tiny that scans won't pick it up.   - You are doing so well, I'm sure you are going to beat this!  No, unfortunately I am not going to beat this.  However, I am hoping for many years of treatment -You are exercising, so you must not have cancer any more.  No, I still have cancer.  If I stop exercising the joint pain increases and my 38 year old body feels like it is 90.  And on and on and on and on... If I don't educate my friends, who will?  If I don't educate them, then I am just perpetuating the early detection/pinktober rah, rah, rah crud.  I answer these questions in a positive way (not poor me...) but I do answer them truthfully. All of that said, I do not believe it is a celebrity's job to educate the public.  She is just a woman who got terrible news like you and me.  I'm sure she is scared and it is not a requirement of her job to share her heath history.  Would I love it if she decided to really dig into this story and do some hard hitting journalism on the actual truth - YES!  Is it requirement because she is a celebrity and has breast cancer - no.  I can absolutely agree that I wish they would stop touting the early detection crud.  I was 36 when I was diagnosed.  I had no family history and was too young for a routine mammogram to be recommended.  I had a normal breast exam by my gynecologist in January at my annual exam.  Yet by the time I saw a doctor in July for a lump I felt, it had already spread to my liver and I was stage IV.  So frankly early detection mumbo jumbo makes me see red.  But, I guess if it gets just one person in for a mammogram who is sitting at home with a lump, then it is worth it for them to make the comment.  *sigh*

Posts.Content: brandall wrote: My sweet Golden Retriever died last night.  Two weeks ago we found out he had cancer (stupid cancer!!!) and he was gone two weeks later.  Awful.  Thankfully my kids were spending the night at their grandparents so they weren't here to see us carry his body out of the house to the vets.  Today we have the hard task of telling them their doggy is gone.  DD (who is 6.5) is really going to take it hard, she has declared that this dog was "her" dog.  I'm comforted by the fact that he didn't suffer.  He was carrying around a dead bird (much to my dismay) 2 hours before he died.  I had to bribe him with treats to get him to drop that darn bird, so he had a dead bird and a treat in his last hours, I'm sure exactly the way he would want to go.  He just went into his kennel, fell asleep and never woke up again. My husband is taking it very hard.  I know it is compounded by the fact that dog had cancer.  I certainly know that my brain was going in that direction thinking about if people will have to carry my body of our house, when the time comes.  I'm so sick and tired of cancer.  Wish me luck in telling our kids today, I'm not looking forward to it :( Brandi - Mother of 2 - Daughter age 6, Son age 3; Liver mets Dx 7/24/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 7/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 8/2/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy 9/11/2012 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy 1/21/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 3/1/2013 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Surgery 3/20/2013 Prophylactic ovary removal Hormonal Therapy 2/21/2014 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 5/31/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 4/9/2015 Afinitor (everolimus) Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: brandall wrote: My sweet Golden Retriever died last night.  Two weeks ago we found out he had cancer (stupid cancer!!!) and he was gone two weeks later.  Awful.  Thankfully my kids were spending the night at their grandparents so they weren't here to see us carry his body out of the house to the vets.  Today we have the hard task of telling them their doggy is gone.  DD (who is 6.5) is really going to take it hard, she has declared that this dog was "her" dog.  I'm comforted by the fact that he didn't suffer.  He was carrying around a dead bird (much to my dismay) 2 hours before he died.  I had to bribe him with treats to get him to drop that darn bird, so he had a dead bird and a treat in his last hours, I'm sure exactly the way he would want to go.  He just went into his kennel, fell asleep and never woke up again. My husband is taking it very hard.  I know it is compounded by the fact that dog had cancer.  I certainly know that my brain was going in that direction thinking about if people will have to carry my body of our house, when the time comes.  I'm so sick and tired of cancer.  Wish me luck in telling our kids today, I'm not looking forward to it :( Brandi - Mother of 2 - Daughter age 6, Son age 3; Liver mets Dx 7/24/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 7/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 8/2/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy 9/11/2012 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy 1/21/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 3/1/2013 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Surgery 3/20/2013 Prophylactic ovary removal Hormonal Therapy 2/21/2014 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 5/31/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 4/9/2015 Afinitor (everolimus) Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: brandall wrote: Hello!  I'm new to this forum.  My name is Brandi and I have a wonderful husband and two beautiful kiddos ages 6 and 3.  I was diagnosed with breast cancer this past July.  I do not have a history of breast cancer in my family.  Ironically when I was diagnosed, I was feeling better than I had in years.  I had started running and finished 2 10k races and was training for a 10 mile race that my husband and I were going to run on a trip we were going to take to Walt Disney World this past fall.  Sadly, we had to cancel that trip :(   I found a lump in my left breast in the middle of May.  I was sitting on the couch and felt an extremely sharp pain in my breast, when I felt the painful spot there was a rather large lump there.  I had had an unremarkable breast exam at my yearly physical in January, so this lump was definitely new.  To be honest, it seemed so large that I can't believe I didn't notice it before that moment.  I e-mailed my doctor and she said that I should definitely be seen, but it was likely a cyst since cancer doesn't hurt, she told me to come in during the middle of my cycle.  Well I had just missed the middle of my cycle so I didn't get an appointment until the early part of June.  I had to cancel that appointment when my step-sister suddenly passed away at age 30.  I needed to go home for the funeral.  When I got back to Colorado I waited a week before I called for a new appointment.  I couldn't get in until July.  I went to my OB/Gyn's office and she felt the lump and referred me for a mammogram and ultrasound.  By the time I was in the parking lot of her office they were calling to make the mammogram appt.  When I went to that appointment a week later, I honestly wasn't worried.  My lump had been throbbing this whole time and EVERYTHING I read indicated that cancer doesn't hurt.  I had the mammogram done and while waiting for my ultrasound, the nurse came back in and asked if they could get some more views for the radiologist.  This was the first moment that I felt some doubt that my lump was nothing.  After I had the ultrasound, the radiologist came in and sat down in front of me.  He grabbed my hand and told me that my mammogram was very disturbing and the ultrasound found 4 masses in my left breast and a suspicious lymph node in my armpit.  He told me he wanted a biopsy done immediately.  He wanted it scheduled that day, but they couldn't get me in until the next day.  While worried, I honestly still felt it could be a cyst.  Well, 3 days later they called and told me that all of my biopsies came back with cancer :( A week later I was in a surgeon's office and 2 days after that I had a left radical mastectomy and an axillary node dissection (7/10 postive nodes).  I kept asking for a PET scan and they said the oncologist would do that.  I wasn't able to get in to see the oncologist for 4 weeks.  They ordered a PET scan, which I had 2 days later and bam a small hot spot in my liver.  Suddenly the doctors stopped dishing out the hope they had been giving me previously.  Very depressing.  The spot was in the middle of my liver and too small to biopsy.  I had 2 MRI's to try and confirm that it was cancer.  The first standard MRI was inconclusive and the 2nd was done with Eovist and the radiologist felt that my "spot" as I call it was likely cancer.  I have never had 100% confirmation, but the fact that it responded so well to chemo and that tumor markers that were once elevated started dropping as it responded, pretty much confirmed it was cancer.  Although, I have to admit that some days I still pretend they were all wrong and it's not cancer.  I did dose dense AC-T chemo for 8 cycles and just completed those in December.  I had a PET scan at the end of December and it came back with "no active cancer" and my liver spot "resolved".  YAY!  I'm about to start radiation on my left chest wall/armpit on the 21st of January.  Then in March I will have a hysterectomy.  I'm so scared of the cancer coming back that I freak out at every little ache and pain :( Well, sorry for the novel!  I'll end this on a positive note.  The trip to WDW that we had to cancel in September due to chemo is back on for May.  I signed up for a super sprint triathlon at the end of June and I just feel like I'm getting my life back.  Having little kids during this process is hard, but also a blessing.  It's hard to lay around feeling sorry for yourself when your 3 year old wants you to play with him and make him some mac and cheese :) Life goes on and it's so beautiful.  I WILL be around to see my kids graduate high school and get married and have kids of their own, I WILL :) Brandi - Mother of 2 - Daughter age 6, Son age 3; Liver mets Dx 7/24/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 7/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 8/2/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy 9/11/2012 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2015 12:30AM brandall wrote: I am on the Paloma 3 trial with Faslodex + a 2/3 chance of getting palbociclib vs. placebo. So far things have been going really well. I started the trial with a peri-gastric lymph node full of cancer and some small liver lesions. I'm 7 months in and my last scans looked so good my oncologist said if she didn't know my history, you wouldn't be able to tell I have cancer at all. I'm currently waiting for new scan results (and freaking out). The palbociclib is a 125mg dose given by pill every day for 21 days and then you have 7 days off. I am not sure I'm on the actual drug because I don't really have any of the neutropenia that is a common side effect of this drug. I feel pretty awesome actually, like I'm running a half marathon in a week kind of awesome. I feel a lot more like myself than I did on Femara. The trial coordinator and my oncologist keep telling me that the neutropenia has really only been a problem for about 30% of the trial participants, so I suppose there is still a chance. It is my understanding that if this drug gets approved with the current approval they are seeking, it will only be allowed to be given as stated in the application. Which I believe at this time is just Letrozole + palbociclib. For it to be given with the faslodex (like the trial I am on they will need to reapply for the new use once the results are in for this phase. I know there are some trials going with Taxol and palbociclib as well. I maybe wrong (and please feel free to correct me), but I don't think oncologists will be able to give it however they like...

I had liver mets that were taken care of with chemo, but now post chemo I'm on tamoxifen.  I'm suspicious my liver mets are growing back (slowly rising tumor markers) but had a clean scan in June, so trying to live in the moment.  I haven't found tamoxifen to be bad at all!  I did have some headaches for the first few weeks, but those have gone away.  I also have some lower back pain on it and hot flashes.  Although, I had a hysterectomy at the same time I went on tamoxifen...so sometimes it's hard to tell which SE belong to the surgery and which belong to the drug!  I did lose about 5lbs just going on the tamoxifen.  Wasn't expecting that - but I'm not complaining!  Good luck with your treatment, and I hope tamoxifen works for you!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2014 12:05PM brandall wrote: "Mods this is precisely why i call you out on this everytime... stage 4 wants to be seperate from bco general population.. yet still wants us to see what they do... no one else sees that as..odd??" This statement really rubs me the wrong way.  Like I am some kind of attention whore who wants everyone to read my problems but doesn't want them to participate.  I'm not sure where you got that impression about stage IV, but I'm pretty sure there are many ladies on here who would love it if everyone couldn't see our posts.  Frankly, I think while most would love a closed group, we also know that most of us came here in desperation looking frantically for someone who could possibly understand the devastating news we just heard and realize that the group needs to stay open for the next woman or man who needs to find us for the same reason.  I come here because there aren't any support groups in my area that fit my particular need.  It is hard to find a group of stage IV girls who are under 40 (and thank goodness for that).  Instead, I get to choose from  a young women's breast cancer support group where people are my age, but they spend the group time complaining about how hard things are with chemo (very validly I might add) or celebrating that they are done (also validly).  You know what?  Both of those things make me feel insanely jealous and sad for myself.  Are those attractive emotions?  NO.  But they too are valid.  How I wish I could complain about chemo knowing that when it is over I'll be done.  How I wish someone blew bubbles for me when my chemo was over...but they didn't, because they knew I would be back.  My other choice for a support group?  A stage IV group where I am the youngest member by over 20 years.  A lot of the talk there is about not seeing grandkids grow up (again super valid).  I sit there and seethe thinking how I wish I had all of those extra years.  How I hope with every fiber of my being that I'll be here for my daughter's first heartbreak, how I hope I'm here to see my little guy as an awkward teenager with gangly limbs and voice cracking, how amazing I'll feel  if I get to see them choose a life partner...and frankly a more realistic goal for me, how I'll be happy to be in my son's pictures on his first day of kindergarten.  Just writing that leaves me in tears.  The idea that I literally might not make it the summer to see my baby go to kindergarten.  So I am sorry, until you walk in these shoes, until you wake up every morning wondering if today is the day cancer wins the battle, wondering if when I die, my children who are both under age 8, should be allowed to see me in my last moments, or if it will be too traumatizing to hear that death rattle coming from their mom, to wonder if at the end I'll be in so much pain that I'll have to be too drugged up to be lucid for my children, to wonder if this is the last soccer season I'll be here, to wonder if this is the last dance recital I'll ever see, to wonder if my husband will get remarried and my children's memories of a mother will be of "her" and not me, because I"ll be a distant memory.  To feel like a horrible person for even thinking that, when I love my family so much I DO hope they are happy, but it is hard to imagine someone coming in and taking over MY life.  Of the two support groups I actually relate more to the stage IV group because they at least KNOW what it is like to have that proverbial bus be the very first thing you think about in the morning, to be the first thing you think about when you lay your head down at night.  They know what it is like to put on a brave face for your loved ones, but to come here and SOB while you are typing out that yet another treatment has failed.  They know what that means, and how little treatments there really are...They understand the ugly side of fear, sadness and jealousy, they KNOW. I frankly don't understand why you would WANT to read these heartbreaking emotions when you don't have to.  I don't really understand what you would gain by posting here and why you would want to come into this thread and aggressively start campaigning to post here.  Why?  I would also like to say that I am not one who really even cares all that much about non stage IV people posting here.  I think this thread started out very respectful.  I don't even care that you disagreed with the original poster, you are certainly entitled to those feelings! I do think your disagreement was written in such a way that you wanted to be controversial.  It is very clear that you feel anger about not being able to post here and I guess I just don't know why?  The problem isn't that non stage IV people want to post here.  The problem is that when they do, for every 20 people who respectfully post and add things when they have advice or feelings that are very valid to the conversation, there is also that one that comes in just to stir things up.  It feels a bit like bullying people who are dying. I won't be coming back into this post.  The original topic already caused me too many emotions, and then the aggressive attack tone of the post caused me to feel sad, defensive, angry and left me sobbing while typing this.  I frankly need all the energy I have to just focus on being a good mommy for my kids when all I want to do is lie down and sleep. All I will say is that ladies on this forum saved my sanity.  Thank goodness this place exists. In my next life I want to more like Fitztwins and respond like she does :) I also apologize for the horrid, grammatical errors in this post...but frankly I'm just too tired to go back and proofread.
Posts.Title: ARRGGH, Amy Robach kebab tangandchris

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2014 03:12PM brandall wrote: I don't begrudge her feeling good or keeping her hair.  I do feel very offended at the tough people statement.  I never had a first go around with bc.  I was diagnosed stage IV right out of the gate, so my tough times aren't ever going away.  I consider myself a tough person and this awful disease is still going to rip me away from my husband and children far too soon.  I will be lucky if I make it to age 40.  I find the whole bc culture about "survivors" and "fighters" and "tough" very insensitive.  The women surviving this disease have not done anything that I haven't done or would do to keep it from killing me.  I would do ANYTHING to stay with my children, ANYTHING.  The difference is the "survivors" are lucky and I apparently am not.  It is not that they fought harder and I deeply resent the implication that it is.  I am happy for the women who are able to go on and have a normal life after their bc experience, but I don't think that that fortunate set of circumstances should be used to belittle the journey of the women who are not so lucky.  We need less propaganda and more research!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 05:21PM brandall wrote: I think about this a lot!  I often think they made a mistake somewhere and this has all been some horrible misunderstanding.  Then I remember that I had 3 biopsies come back positive for cancer, a pathology report that said it was cancer and a retesting of my tumors that STILL say it is cancer *sigh*  Right before I was diagnosed (but clearly had cancer) I felt the best I've ever felt in my life.  I had lost 36lbs (26 of which I regained on chemo *yay*) and was running 10k races and training for a 10 mile race.  I felt FABULOUS!  It was and still is so hard to  believe that there was cancer running amok in my body when I felt GREAT.  I feel less great now (although still good) since I'm still rebounding from chemo and currently doing radiation on my chest wall.   I am a HUGE hypochondriac now though, pain in my back - eek cancer, pain in my upper right quadrant - eek the liver tumor is back, pain in my head - brain met, cough - met in my lung...it never ends and my poor husband has to talk me down off the ledge a lot LOL.
